questions.text: Which of the following is not true about medulloblastoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical treatment not done

 

Option C:

 

Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor that primarily affects the cerebellum and is more common in children. Surgical intervention is a crucial component of the management of this tumor and is performed to remove as much of the tumor as possible.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Medulloblastoma is a radiosensitive tumor and radiation therapy is often part of the treatment plan.

 

Option B: Medulloblastoma commonly spreads through the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), leading to leptomeningeal dissemination.

 

Option D: Medulloblastoma predominantly occurs in the pediatric age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical treatment is indeed performed for medulloblastoma and it is an important part of the management strategy for this type of tumor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female in her third trimester of pregnancy presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-week history of itchy, tense blisters centralized on her abdomen, especially around the umbilical area. The blisters are on an erythematous base and she denies any prior history of similar lesions. She has no significant medical history and her pregnancy has been uneventful until these skin changes. Examination does not reveal involvement of the mucous membranes. Based on the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigoid Gestationis

 

Option D.

 

Pemphigoid gestationis / Gestational pemphigoid / Herpes gestationis

 

  • This autoimmune blistering disorder occurs during pregnancy, typically in the second or third trimester, and is characterized by pruritic, tense blisters on the abdomen, often starting near the umbilicus.

 

 

  • It is associated with antibodies to BP180 and BP230, similar to bullous pemphigoid but is pregnancy specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Incorrect because it typically affects older individuals and is not associated with pregnancy.

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • Incorrect because this condition presents with grouped vesicles and intense pruritus, often on extensor surfaces, and is associated with celiac disease.

 

Option C. PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy):

 

  • Incorrect because PUPPP usually presents with urticarial papules and plaques, starts in the stretch marks of the abdomen, and typically does not involve the formation of blisters.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid gestationis is a pruritic, vesiculobullous disorder of pregnancy presenting with tense blisters around the umbilical area, typically occurring in the second or third trimester, without mucosal involvement.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 115.13

questions.text: A primigravida in her 3rd Trimester develops intensely itchy grouped vesicles in the periumbilical area. A diagnosis of Herpes gestation is made based on these features.  Which of the following is INCORRECT statement among the following options regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes Simplex Virus- 1 is responsible for Cross Reaction with Skin Antigens & Antibody Formation

 

Option B.

 

  • This is an incorrect statement. Despite its name, Herpes gestationis is not caused by Herpes simplex virus; it's a misnomer. The condition is autoimmune in nature

 

Herpes gestationis or pemphigoid gestationis

 

  • It is a variant of Bullous pemphigoid in pregnancy (NOT due to Herpes virus) and is associated with antibodies against BP-180 / BPAG-2.
  • The initial site of involvement is the periumbilical region.

 

 

  • It presents in the 2nd or 3rd trimesters with itchy, grouped vesicles (so Herpes word used in the name of the disease) in the periumbilical area that later spread to the abdomen, trunk, thighs.

 

Prognosis:

 

  • It flares in the intrapartum / Delivery period and tends to resolves spontaneously in the postpartum period.
  • Future outcome: It can recur in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It resolves spontaneously in postpartum period

 

  • The condition resolves spontaneously in the postpartum period, although flare-ups can occur with menstruation or subsequent pregnancies.

 

Option C. Associated with antibodies against BP180 antigen

 

  • The condition is associated with antibodies against BP180 antigen, which is a hemidesmosomal protein involved in the structural integrity of the skin.

 

Option D. Variant of Bullous Pemphigoid

 

  • Pemphigoid Gestationis is considered a variant of Bullous Pemphigoid, occurring specifically during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid Gestationis, the autoimmune response targets BP180 antigen, and it is a pregnancy-related variant of Bullous Pemphigoid that typically resolves postpartum.
  • It is not related to Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology- 4th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 554

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient complains of the following intensely itchy rash over her elbows, knees as shown in the image below. She is also a known case of celiac disease & she strictly follows a gluten-free diet, which has resulted in improvement of her diarrhea. However, the following itchy skin lesions have persisted despite her altered diet. What is the Drug of choice for this patient & what is the characteristic DIF finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapsone & Granular Deposits of IgA in Dermal Papillae

 

Option A.

 

  • Dapsone is the drug of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis and can provide rapid relief of itching. The characteristic DIF finding in dermatitis herpetiformis is granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae.
  • The image and history presented suggest a dermatological condition associated with celiac disease.
  • Given the intense itching, the locations over elbows and knees, and the association with celiac disease, the most likely diagnosis is dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Steroids & Linear deposits of IgA in Basement membrane Zone.

 

  • While steroids may be used in a variety of dermatological conditions, they are not the first-line treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • Additionally, linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone are indicative of a different condition, such as linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Dapsone& Granular deposits of IgG in dermal papillae.

 

  • Although Dapsone is the correct treatment, the characteristic DIF finding in dermatitis herpetiformis is granular IgA, not IgG deposits.

 

Option D.Steroids & Linear deposits of IgG in Basement membrane Zone.

 

  • This option suggests a diagnosis of Bullous pemphigoid and does not correspond to dermatitis herpetiformis, which is characterized by IgA deposits.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with an intensely itchy rash over the elbows and knees and a history of celiac disease, the drug of choice is Dapsone, and the characteristic DIF finding is granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae.

 

Ref:Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.52-50.54

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl child presents to OPD with blisters over perioral area & other periorificial areas which are arranged annularly giving a ‘crown of jewels’ appearance (Image given below). Direct immunofluorescence microscopy revealed linear IgA deposition in Basement membrane zone. What is the most likely diagnosis & what is the drug of choice in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood & Dapsone

 

Option C.

 

  • The given image showing blisters over perioral area & other periorificial areas in an annular fashion giving a ‘crown of jewels’ appearance with linear deposition of IgA at the dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic for linear IgA disease (LABD) or chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) or IgA pemphigoid.

 

 

  • It is the most common immunobullous disease in infants and children.
  • It has Bimodal age group distribution, i.e., it may occur <5 years or at 60-65 years of age.
  • It occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and can be triggered by drugs like vancomycin, penicillin, and NSAIDs.

 

Management:

 

  • While dapsone is primarily a bactericidal drug, it also has an anti-inflammatory action by decreasing the action of neutrophil enzymes. Hence, it is useful in the treatment of IgA pemphigoid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid

 

  • It is typically a disease of the elderly and is characterized by subepidermal blisters with linear IgG and C3 deposition, not IgA.
  • Dapsone is not the first-line treatment for bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option B. Chronic bullous disease of childhood (CBDC), also known as linear IgA disease.

 

  • It is the correct diagnosis based on the description, but azathioprine is not the drug of choice.
  • It is used as a second-line or adjunctive therapy when dapsone is contraindicated or insufficient.

 

Option D. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

 

  • It is a hereditary condition characterized by skin fragility and blistering due to cytoskeletal protein mutations.
  • Genetic counselling may be of value for familial planning, but the condition does not present with linear IgA deposition, nor is it treated with dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a child presenting with annularly arranged periorificial blisters and linear IgA deposition at the basement membrane zone, the most likely diagnosis is Chronic bullous disease of childhood, and the drug of choice is dapsone.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page N50.33

questions.text: A patient presents with the Tense bullous lesions associated with itching. Histopathology revealed Subepidermal blistering. What is the diagnosis of this condition & what are the antigens against which autoantibodies are most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous Pemphigoid & BP180

 

Option A.

 

  • Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal vesiculobullous disorder where there is at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ).
  • Tense bullae which are associated with itching are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. The bullae are Nikolsky negative as acantholysis is absent.
  • Autoantibodies against BP180 are most commonly seen in this condition.

 

BP180 is also known as BPAg2, and it is seen in 75-90% of bullous pemphigoid patients. Autoantibodies against BP230or BPAg1 are recognized in 50-70% of bullous pemphigoid patients.

 

 

Histopathology of Bullous Pemphigoid showing Subepidermal split:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris & Desmoglein 3.

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with flaccid blisters, not tense ones, and the blisters are intraepidermal due to acantholysis.
  • The main autoantigen is Desmoglein 3, a desmosomal protein.

 

Option C. Bullous Pemphigoid & BP280.

 

  • This option is incorrect because BP280 (collagen type VII) is not the primary

antigen in Bullous Pemphigoid; BP180 is the correct antigen.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris & Desmoglein 1.

 

  • While Desmoglein 1 is indeed a target antigen in some cases of Pemphigus vulgaris (usually in combination with Desmoglein 3), the description provided does not match Pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with supra basal intra-epidermal blistering and flaccid bullae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with tense bullae and histopathology showing subepidermal blistering, the diagnosis is Bullous Pemphigoid, and the autoantibodies are most commonly directed against the BP180 antigen.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.10

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with a resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. On examination, there is a characteristic "pill-rolling" tremor observed. The patient also exhibits postural instability. Which neurotransmitter is primarily affected in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dopamine

 

Option D:

 

Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. The loss of dopamine-producing neurons leads to the classic motor symptoms of resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. The characteristic "pill-rolling" tremor is often observed, and postural instability may develop as the disease progresses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Changes in serotonin levels are more associated with mood disorders.

 

Option B: While imbalances in acetylcholine and dopamine play a role in movement disorders, the primary deficit in Parkinson's disease is related to dopamine deficiency.

 

Option C: GABA is an inhibitory neurotransmitter, and alterations in GABAergic transmission are not the primary cause of Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neurotransmitter primarily affected in the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease is Dopamine, which is depleted due to degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, leading to characteristic symptoms like resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1293

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient sustains a traumatic injury resulting in damage to nervous tissue. The subsequent healing process involves the formation of scar tissue at the site of injury. Which of the following cell types is primarily responsible for the formation of scar tissue during the repair of nervous tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuroglia

 

Option A:

 

  • “Gliosis is the most important histopathological indicator of CNS injury regardless of its etiology and is characterized by both hypertrophy and hyperplasia.” The chief cell involved in this reaction is an astrocyte.
  • Please remember that the oligodendrocytes and the ependyma do not participate in active response to injury.
  • Microglia is the fixed macrophage system in the CNS.

 

Neuroglia, particularly astrocytes, are responsible for the formation of scar tissue within the central nervous system (CNS) through a process known as gliosis, which occurs in response to injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Fibroblasts are the primary cell type responsible for scar formation in peripheral tissues, but not typically within the CNS, as they produce collagen and other extracellular matrix components leading to the formation of connective tissue scars.

 

Option C: Axons do not form scar tissue but can be involved in the regeneration process in the peripheral nervous system under certain conditions.

 

Option D: Microglia are the resident macrophages of the CNS, involved in the immune response and clean-up after injury but are not the primary cells responsible for scar tissue formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cell type primarily responsible for the formation of scar tissue during the repair of nervous tissue is Neuroglia, as astrocytes, a type of glial cell, play a crucial role in the gliosis process that leads to scar formation in the CNS.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1255

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient presents to the neurology clinic with a progressive decline in memory and cognitive function over the past few years. The family reports episodes of visual hallucinations and fluctuations in alertness. Cognitive testing demonstrates impaired memory recall and difficulty with executive functions. An MRI of the brain shows atrophy in the temporal and parietal lobes. Biopsy of brain tissue was done. Which of the following features is not typically associated with the pathology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lewy bodies

 

Option D:

 

Lewy bodies are not a characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's disease is primarily characterized by the presence of neurofibrillary tangles and senile (neuritic) plaques in the brain. Amyloid angiopathy, which involves the deposition of amyloid protein in blood vessel walls, is also associated with Alzheimer's disease. However, Lewy bodies are more commonly associated with other neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Lewy body dementia and Parkinson's disease dementia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Neurofibrillary tangles: These are twisted tangles of tau protein within nerve cells.

 

Option B: Senile (neuritic) plaques: These are abnormal clusters of beta-amyloid protein that accumulate between nerve cells.

 

Option C: Amyloid angiopathy: It involves the deposition of amyloid protein in blood vessel walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy bodies are not typically associated with the pathology of Alzheimer's disease, which is characterized by neurofibrillary tangles, senile neuritic plaques, and amyloid angiopathy.

 

Lewy bodies are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions composed of alpha-synuclein, seen in:

 

  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

 

Ref: Robbins 10th / 1275

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and persistent tinnitus. Physical examination reveals a non-tender mass in the vicinity of cranial nerve VIII. An MRI indicates a well-circumscribed mass in the internal acoustic meatus, and a subsequent biopsy is performed. Histologically, the tissue demonstrates distinct regions of cellularity with areas showing dense proliferation of spindle cells, while others show less density. There is also evidence of nuclear palisading. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schwannoma

 

Option A:

 

This tumor arises from Schwann cells, which produce the myelin sheath of peripheral nerves. The biopsy is consistent with a schwannoma due to the presence of Antoni A areas (hypercentric, organized cellularity with nuclear palisading) and Antoni B areas (hypocellular, less organized regions).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Lymphoma: Lymphomas are neoplasms of the lymphatic system and would present histologically with an infiltration of lymphoid cells, which does not correspond to the nuclear palisading and alternating cellularity described in the stem.

 

Option C: Leukemia: This is a hematopoietic stem cell malignancy primarily affecting the bone marrow and blood. Histology of a solid mass would not reveal the characteristic findings of leukemia, such as blasts or excessive leukocytes.

 

Option D: Angiofibroma: Angiofibroma, often a benign tumor of adolescent males, would show a stromal and vascular component histologically, which is not described in the biopsy findings of the question stem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic histological features of schwannomas are Antoni A areas, with hypercellular tissue and nuclear palisading, and Antoni B areas, which are less cellular.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p1237

questions.text: Mitotic figures and giant cells are seen in which of the following tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Benign and malignant pheochromocytoma

 

Option B:

 

Pheochromocytomas are difficult to diagnose exclusively from the histological appearance. Cellular and nuclear pleomorphism, including the presence of giant cells, and mitotic figures are often seen in benign pheochromocytomas. So, the definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases.

 

Pheochromocytomas, whether benign or malignant, can exhibit cellular and nuclear pleomorphism, which includes the presence of giant cells and mitotic figures. The presence of these features does not correlate with malignancy, as malignancy in pheochromocytoma is defined by the presence of metastasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Thyroid cancers can indeed present with mitotic figures, especially in more aggressive forms such as anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. However, giant cells are particularly characteristic of certain inflammatory conditions such as subacute thyroiditis, rather than thyroid neoplasms.

 

Option C: Benign and malignant liver tumors \ such as hepatocellular carcinoma can show mitotic figures, indicating a high proliferative rate. However, giant cells are more typical of specific liver pathologies such as giant cell hepatitis, not necessarily of benign or malignant liver tumors.

 

Option D: In renal tumors, mitotic figures are also indicative of a higher grade of malignancy, especially in clear cell renal carcinoma. Giant cells are not a characteristic feature of common benign or malignant renal tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological presence of mitotic figures and giant cells in pheochromocytomas is not indicative of malignancy; instead, malignancy is confirmed by the presence of metastatic disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1127

questions.text: Most common thyroid cancer after radiation exposure is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Papillary cancer

 

Option A:

 

  • There is a marked increase in the incidence of papillary carcinomas among children exposed to ionizing radiation (particularly during the first 2 decades of life).
  • Deficiency of dietary iodine (and so, goiter) is linked with a higher frequency of follicular carcinomas.

 

Exposure to ionizing radiation, especially during the first two decades of life, significantly increases the risk of developing papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Medullary cancer: Medullary thyroid cancer arises from parafollicular C-cells and is typically associated with genetic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, not with radiation exposure.

 

Option C: Follicular cancer: While not associated with radiation exposure, the incidence of follicular carcinoma is higher in areas with iodine deficiency.

 

Option D: Anaplastic cancer: Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer that generally occurs in the elderly population and is not associated with radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer associated with childhood exposure to ionizing radiation, which can significantly increase the risk of this cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1086

questions.text: About papillary carcinoma of thyroid, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early metastasis with poor prognosis

 

Option C:

 

Although papillary thyroid carcinoma can metastasize early, particularly to regional lymph nodes, it usually maintains a good prognosis and is often curable.

 

This does not worsen prognosis significantly.

 

Even with lymph node metastasis, survival remains excellent.

 

Distant metastasis (to lungs or bone) is rare, and when present, prognosis may be slightly worse but still much better than most other cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Associated with BRAF mutation: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with BRAF gene mutation.

 

Option B. Psammoma body present in 50% cases: Psammoma bodies are calcifications that are often found in papillary thyroid carcinoma but may not be present in as many as 50% of cases.

 

Option D. Spreads by the lymphatic route: This is true. Papillary thyroid carcinoma commonly spreads to regional lymph nodes via lymphatics.

 

This typically involves:

 

  • Cervical lymph nodes (neck)
  • Jugular lymph chain

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid typically has a favorable prognosis, even with early lymphatic spread, contrasting with other cancers where early metastasis often correlates with a poor prognosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1086

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented to the dermatology clinic with itchy and hyperpigmented plaques in cubital and popliteal fossa as shown in image. Her personal history reveals a chronic & recurrent course of these lesions; family history is positive for asthma. Identify the FALSE statement related to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has a Flexural Distribution in Infantile Phase

 

Option C:

 

  • The image showing Scratch Marks & Excoriations due to Pruritic Lesion at a Flexural Site along with a personal history of chronic & recurrent course & a family history of atopy (Asthma) is suggestive of Atopic Dermatitis (AD) or Atopic Eczema (AE) (Option A)
  • Flexural distribution is seen in Childhood & Adult Phase & Extensor distribution in Infantile Phase.
  • It is a Chronic or chronically relapsing Inflammatory Condition.
  • The first site of involvement in infants with atopic eczema is the face.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected

 

 

  • Erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, which frequently begin in early childhood, are how it manifests.
  • Later, the lesions develop excoriation and Lichenification. It frequently has a relationship with secondary infections & skin dryness.
  • The UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of Atopic dermatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema):

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus three or more of the following:
  1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  3. History of a generally dry skin
  4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)
     

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge
     

Dennie morgan fold

 

 

Complications:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis in infants typically involves the face and extensor surfaces rather than flexural areas, which are more commonly affected in older children and adults.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 41 Page No 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color of the Human Skin depends upon the Number of Melanocytes.

 

Option A: Color of the human skin depends upon the number of melanocytes

 

The color of the human skin does NOT depend on the number of melanocytes.

 

The following factors determine the skin's color:

 

  1. The concentration of melanin within melanocytes
  2. The quantity and size of melanosomes
  3. The extent to which melanin is transferred into keratinocytes.

 

Melanin, a pigment produced by melanocytes, is what gives skin its color.

 

Melanocytes are dendritic cells that are found in the stratum basale layer of epidermis and are descended from neural crest cells.

 

The cell organelles known as melanosomes are where each melanocyte stores the melanin it produces.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: These melanosomes are distributed to the 36 keratinocytes that make up the "epidermal melanin" unit via the dendritic processes of melanocytes. (The ratio of the epidermal melanin unit is 36 keratinocytes: 1 melanocyte)

 

Option B: Melasma in pregnant women is called as Chloasma or mask of pregnancy.

 

Clinical Image depicting Melasma

 

 

  • The third trimester of pregnancy is when chloasma is most prevalent and is most noticeable in brunettes.
  • It results from elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone stimulating melanocyte activity.
  • Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper-functional melanocytes. Once the pregnancy is over, it resolves naturally.
  • The most frequent cause of chronic facial melanosis is melasma. Hyperpigmented macules that are more pronounced after exposure to sunlight are its primary symptom. Upper lip, malar, forehead, and chin are the main areas of the body affected by this hyper melanosis. Women between the ages of 20 and 40 are more likely to have it.
  • It is due to increased levels of estrogen & progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes. Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper functional melanocytes. It resolves on its own after pregnancy.
  • It is frequently seen in women on OCPs.

 

Woods lamp examination is useful to differentiate various types of Melasma, level of pigmentation & treatment response:

 

 

  • Melasma is more Chronic & requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:
  • Kligman triple combination- Topical Hydroquinone + Tretinoin + Steroid compound cream (First Line)
  • Hydroquinone (reduces Tyrosinase Activity)
  • Kojic Acid (Tyrosinase Inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels

 

Option D: Para-Tertiary Butyl Phenol is the culprit behind bindi Leukoderma (PTBP). It is present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

Clinical Image depicting Bindi Leucoderma

 

 

  • This condition is known as chemical or contact leukoderma, in which the chemical increases sensitivity and causes the melanocytes in the area of contact to undergo apoptosis.
  • Additionally, there is proof that azo dyes, which share structural similarities with tyrosine and compete with it for the binding of the tyrosinase enzyme, can directly inhibit melanogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct identification of skin colour being determined by melanin production and NOT by the number of melanocytes is crucial for understanding the pathophysiology of pigmentary disorders.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 2.17, 68.11, 75.19, 88.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1119-1121

  • A benign inflammatory skin condition called discoid lupus erythematosus usually affects the face and scalp, associated scarring alopecia (Option B) is seen.
  • It has distinct, red, scaly patches that can vary in size.
  • These patches heal with atrophy, scarring, and pigmentary changes.
  • The most common type of disease is the circumscribed or discoid form, which mainly affects the cheeks, nose bridge, ears, side of the neck, and scalp. (Option A)

 

The scalp-specific discoid lupus erythematosus with follicular plugging (Scarring alopecia) is depicted in the image below.

 

 

  • The skin lesions in discoid or chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus are well-defined erythematous patches with adherentscaling and peripheral hyperpigmentation.
  • The underside of the scale reveals horny plugs that have occupied dilated pilosebaceous canals when the scale is removed.
  • This sign is known as the "tin-tack" sign.
  • The first-line treatment for localized lesions is topical corticosteroids. (Option C)
  • Hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are oral antimalarial drugs that can be used along with oral steroids and have a good response rate. (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) typically presents with scarring alopecia when it affects the scalp, distinguishing it from non-scarring forms of alopecia.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 51, Page no’s 51.4-51.10

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, with a background of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, long-term alcohol abuse, and homelessness, is hospitalized due to acute pneumonia. During a ward examination, you observe a brownish-red discoloration on his face, neck, forearms, and lower legs, accompanied by skin scaling and cracks. He reports difficulties with eating and drinking, ongoing vomiting, diarrhea, and appears somewhat disoriented. Which vitamin deficiency might be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. B3 (niacin)


Explanation
•    Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the four Ds: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia, and potentially Death if untreated. 
•    The skin changes noted as brown-red discoloration with scaling and cracking, particularly when exposed to sunlight, are indicative of dermatitis. 
•    The gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea, along with neurological signs such as disorientation, point towards the systemic effects of niacin deficiency, encompassing both digestive and mental disturbances.


Other Options
Option A. B1 (thiamine): Deficiency leads to beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the cardiovascular and nervous systems, respectively. It does not typically cause the dermatological or extensive gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this patient.


Option B. B2 (riboflavin): Deficiency of riboflavin can cause angular cheilitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, but these symptoms are distinct from the extensive skin discoloration and systemic symptoms described.


Option D. B6 (pyridoxine): Deficiency primarily presents with peripheral neuropathy, irritability, depression, and dermatitis, but unlike niacin deficiency, it does not typically result in the severe digestive and mental symptoms observed in this case.


Educational Objective:
•    The crucial fact to remember from this case is that niacin deficiency, or pellagra, presents with a characteristic combination of symptoms including dermatitis (skin discoloration and scaling), diarrhea, dementia (disorientation), and can be fatal if untreated. 


Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 63 Page Number 63.4

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral lower extremity swelling and fatigue for the past several months. He has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and obesity. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum creatinine and proteinuria. A renal biopsy is performed, which demonstrates deposition of amyloid proteins in the glomeruli. Which of the following types of diabetes mellitus is most commonly associated with this renal complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II DM

 

Option C:

 

Type II DM is associated with the deposition of amyloid in the pancreatic islets, contributing to β-cell dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is characterized by monogenic defects of β-cell function but is not typically associated with amyloid deposition in the islets.

 

Option B: Type I DM is an autoimmune disorder leading to β-cell destruction and does not typically involve amyloid deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid deposition in the islets of Langerhans is a feature specifically associated with Type II diabetes mellitus, which can contribute to the dysfunction of insulin-secreting pancreatic β-cells.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 261

questions.text: What is the primary contributor to insulin resistance in liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steatosis

 

Option B:

 

The accumulation of fat in the liver, or hepatic steatosis, is closely associated with insulin resistance. It impairs the liver's response to insulin, particularly affecting the inhibition of gluconeogenesis and increasing insulin resistance in peripheral tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Decreased insulin release: This refers to a problem with insulin secretion from the pancreas, not resistance at the level of hepatic or peripheral tissues and does not directly relate to liver disease.

 

Option C: Hepatocyte dysfunction: While hepatocyte dysfunction can contribute to metabolic disturbances, it is a broader term that includes various liver impairments, not specific to insulin resistance.

 

Option D: Decreased ‘C’ peptide level: C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production. Lower levels may indicate reduced insulin secretion but are not a direct cause of insulin resistance in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic steatosis, or fatty liver disease, is a significant contributor to insulin resistance, which impairs both the liver's response to insulin and the peripheral action of insulin.

 

Ref: Robbin 10th/ 1140, Joslin’s Diabetes Mellitus 14/e p436

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of jaundice and pruritus. Liver biopsy reveals characteristic "onion skin fibrosis" around the bile ducts. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the histological finding described?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary sclerosing cholangitis

 

Option B:

 

"Onion skin fibrosis" refers to a characteristic histological finding in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a chronic, progressive cholestatic liver disease characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Primary biliary cirrhosis is a distinct autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of small bile ducts within the liver. "Onion skin fibrosis" is not a typical histological finding in primary biliary cirrhosis.

 

Option C: Extrahepatic biliary fibrosis: This term is nonspecific and not commonly used as a diagnosis.

 

Option D: Congenital hepatic fibrosis is a developmental disorder of the liver and is not associated with onion skin fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is associated with characteristic "onion skin fibrosis" around bile ducts and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, reflecting bile duct inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 861

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and joint pains presents with skin hyperpigmentation and elevated serum ferritin. A liver biopsy is performed, and the resulting slide is shown. The patient's liver biopsy is notable for a blue staining pattern within the hepatocytes. Given below is the histopathology of liver biopsy of a patient with hemochromatosis. Which of the following stain has been used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prussian blue

 

Option A:

 

This iron stain, also known as Perls' Prussian blue, detects ferric iron by turning it blue. It is specifically used for the detection of iron overload in tissues, as seen in hemochromatosis.

 

Explanation

 

Option B: Alcian blue: Alcian blue stains acidic polysaccharides and glycosaminoglycans in tissues blue, which is used to identify mucopolysaccharides. It is not used for iron staining.

 

Option C: Von Kossa: The Von Kossa stain is used to detect calcium salts, which appear black under microscopy. This would not be the appropriate stain for identifying iron deposits in the liver.

 

Option D: Crystal violet: Crystal violet is a basic dye that stains the components of cells purple or blue-violet and is often used in Gram staining of bacteria. It is not used for the detection of iron in tissue samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This stain is used to detect iron deposits in tissues and is characteristic of the pathology seen in hemochromatosis, where iron accumulation occurs within the hepatocytes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 849

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents with abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Liver biopsy reveals abnormal intracellular inclusions in hepatocytes. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrates the presence of intermediate filaments. Which protein is the major component of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytokeratin

Option B:

Mallory bodies are visible as eosinophilic cytoplasmic clumps in hepatocytes. They are composed of tangled skeins of cytokeratin intermediate filaments such as cytokeratin 8 and 18, in complex with other proteins such as ubiquitin.

 

 

Cytokeratins are intermediate filament proteins found in epithelial cells. The intracellular inclusions seen in hepatocytes, known as Mallory bodies, are composed primarily of cytokeratin, particularly cytokeratin 8 and 18.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein found in mesenchymal cells and is not typically associated with hepatocyte inclusions. It's more commonly related to cells of mesenchymal origin.

 

Option C: Keratins are a broader family of fibrous structural proteins; cytokeratins are a subtype found in epithelial cells. In the context of liver pathology, it is more accurate to specify cytokeratins as the component of the inclusions.

 

Option D: Collagen is a structural protein found in connective tissues, such as tendons and ligaments, and is not involved in the formation of Mallory bodies within hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mallory bodies, which are abnormal intracellular inclusions found in hepatocytes, especially in conditions like alcoholic liver disease, are composed predominantly of cytokeratin intermediate filaments (CK 8 and 18).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 843

questions.text: A patient with unconjugated bilirubinemia has increased excretion of urobilinogen in his urine. This can be seen in all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biliary cirrhosis

 

Option D:

 

Biliary cirrhosis primarily affects the conjugated bilirubin pathway, and it is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: G6PD deficiency can lead to hemolysis, resulting in increased unconjugated bilirubin production. Therefore, it is associated with increased urobilinogen excretion.

 

Option B: Hemolytic anemia, where red blood cells are destroyed prematurely, increase the production of unconjugated bilirubin. This can lead to increased urobilinogen in the urine.

 

Option C: Hereditary spherocytosis is a hemolytic disorder characterized by spherical-shaped red blood cells, leading to increased bilirubin production. It is associated with increased urobilinogen excretion.

 

Educational objective:

 

Biliary cirrhosis is associated with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 855

questions.text: A 28 year young female Katrina present to your OPD with complaints of suprapubic pain, urinary frequency and dysuria. She also passed blood in last voided urine about 30 minutes ago. Her urinanalysis demonstrate the presence of pyuria but no white cell casts. On physical examination, she has suprapubic tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystitis

Option C:

Cystitis: Characterized by symptoms of lower urinary tract infection, including suprapubic pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. Pyuria and hematuria are common findings in cystitis, but white cell casts are typically absent.

The clinical presentation of the patient in the stem of the question is of cystitis, which is characterized by pyuria and hematuria but absence of white cell casts in the urine.

Explanation:

Option A: Acute pyelonephritis: Typically presents with fever, flank pain, and systemic symptoms along with pyuria, leukocytosis, and white cell casts in the urine. Suprapubic pain and dysuria are less common in acute pyelonephritis compared to cystitis.

Option B: Chronic pyelonephritis: Usually develops as a result of recurrent acute pyelonephritis or chronic urinary tract obstruction. It may present with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, malaise, and flank pain, but suprapubic tenderness and dysuria are less characteristic.

Option D: Fanconi syndrome: Is a rare renal tubular disorder characterized by defects in proximal tubular function leading to renal wasting of electrolytes, amino acids, glucose, and low molecular weight proteins. It typically presents with metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, glycosuria, and aminoaciduria, but not with symptoms of urinary tract infection.

Educational Objective:

The clinical features and diagnostic findings associated with cystitis, are lower urinary tract symptoms, pyuria, and hematuria, but absence of white cell casts in the urine.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 928)

choices.text: Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells
Deposition of electron dense material in the basement membrane

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presented with generalized edema. Urine examination revealed marked albuminuria. Serum biochemical examinations showed hypoalbuminemia with hyperlipidemia. Kidney biopsy was undertaken. On light microscopic examination, the kidney appeared normal. Electron microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fusion of foot process of the glomerular epi­thelial cells

 

Option A:

 

Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells is characteristic of minimal change disease. Electron microscopy will reveal effacement or fusion of the podocyte foot processes without immune complex deposition or complement activation.

 

The child is presenting with features likely of Nephrotic syndrome whose most frequent cause in children is minimal change disease or lipoid nephrosis.

 

  • Light microscopy there is no abnormality whereas on electron microscopy there is fusion of foot pro­cesses of the glomerular epithelial cells with normal glomeruli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rarefaction of the glomerular basement membrane is not a feature of MCD but may be seen in other kidney diseases, such as Alport syndrome.

 

Option C: Deposition of electron-dense material in the basement membrane is typically observed in diseases such as membranous nephropathy, not MCD.

 

Option D: A thin basement membrane is characteristic of thin basement membrane disease, a condition separate from MCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary finding in minimal change disease on electron microscopy is the effacement or fusion of podocyte foot processes, which helps in distinguishing it from other glomerular diseases that may present with normal findings on light microscopy but show specific abnormalities on electron microscopy.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 914)

questions.text: On sectioning of an organ at the time of autopsy, a focal, wedge-shaped firm area is seen accompanied by extensive hemorrhage, with a red appearance. The lesion has a base on the surface of the organ. This finding is typically of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lung with pulmonary thromboembolism

Option A:

Image of pulmonary infarct (marked by arrow)

  • The morphology is characteristically present as red (hemorrhagic) infarct. The red infarcts are seen in lung, liver and intestine.
  • White infarcts are seen in brain, spleen, kidney and heart.

Lung with pulmonary thromboembolism is characterized by a wedge-shaped hemorrhagic infarct. Due to the dual blood supply from the bronchial and pulmonary arteries, these infarcts are typically red (hemorrhagic).

Explanation:

Option B: Heart with coronary thrombosis typically results in pale (white) infarcts due to the loss of blood supply to the myocardium, unless reperfusion occurs, which can lead to a hemorrhagic appearance.

Option C: Liver with hypovolemic shock may not typically present with a wedge-shaped lesion but can show patchy necrosis due to global hypoperfusion.

Option D: Kidney with septic embolus can lead to infarcts that are generally pale (white) due to the organ's end-arterial blood supply, except in the case of a dual blood supply or reperfusion, which can lead to a hemorrhagic appearance.

Educational Objective:

Pulmonary thromboembolism is a condition that can present with a wedge-shaped, hemorrhagic (red) infarct on organ sectioning during autopsy, with the lesion's base on the organ surface.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 135)

questions.text: A 26-year-old man complains of burning pain when urinating. He reluctantly acknowledges that four days ago, he engaged in unprotected sexual activity. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

 

Option D:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae
 

  • The patient's symptoms, which appeared four days after unprotected sex, are consistent with urethritis brought on by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, whose incubation period is one to five days.
  • Male gonococcal infection most frequently manifests as acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Depending on the nature of the sexual contact, pharyngeal and rectal infections can also happen.
     
  • However, the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may also be affected. In women, the cervix is the primary site of infection.
     
  • Excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, profound dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and intermenstrual bleeding are among the symptoms.
     
  • Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is most frequently brought on by Chlamydia, which has a 1–3-week incubation period.
    Typically, only dysuria is present, but mucopurulent discharge can also happen. NGU can also be brought on by Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis:
 

  • It is also a common cause of urethritis, but it typically causes a less pronounced or even asymptomatic presentation compared to gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Mycoplasma genitalium:
 

  • It is another cause of urethritis but is less common than gonorrhea and chlamydia and often causes milder symptoms.

 

Option C. Trichomonas vaginalis:
 

  • This causes trichomoniasis which typically presents with a frothy discharge and is more commonly symptomatic in females than males.



Educational Objective:

 

  • When a male patient presents with purulent urethral discharge and reports recent unprotected sexual activity, the most likely diagnosis is gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Identification is typically confirmed through culture of the discharge.

questions.text: After 14 hours of receiving Injection Penicillin for her early latent syphilis, a 35-year-old woman suddenly develops a high-grade fever, myalgia, and bone pain. Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Penicillin cannot be used in future

 

Option B: Penicillin cannot be used in future

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain, and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

 

Explanation:

 

  • A febrile reaction occurring within 24 hours of penicillin therapy for syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction.
  • Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is self-limiting and is due to lipoprotein release from the dying treponemes, which trigger cytokine release.
  • The patient presents with flu-like symptoms and exacerbation of skin lesions. Fever rarely lasts more than 8 hours. Symptoms may be controlled by antipyretics. It is not a contraindication for penicillin use in the future.
  • Penicillin allergy is a contraindication for further use. JH reactions must be differentiated from penicillin allergy.
  • Constitutional Symptoms such as Fever, Joint Pain, Hypotension along with Worsening of Skin Lesions. Treatment : Symptomatic

 

Allergic reactions can be early or late as follows:

 

  • Early type- anaphylaxis within 1 hour of the first dose.
  • Late type- rash after several doses of penicillin.

 

In Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction, Corticosteroids are only indicated in pregnant women and patients with neurosyphilis in whom the reaction can be more serious and life-threatening sequelae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain, and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has come down with painful lesions as shown below. She tells you that vesicles were present 5 days back over the same site and says that she is allergic to penicillin. On examination, she has bilateral tender lymphadenopathy. Which kit will you use to treat her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red kit

 

Option B: Red kit

 

  • The treatment of Genital Herpes involves antiviral therapy, which is typically provided in the red kit.

  • It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days, which is effective against the herpes simplex virus.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical picture of multiple, grouped painful ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy in this patient points to a diagnosis of herpes genitalis infection by HSV-2.

  • It is treated with a red kit. In herpetic genital ulcer disease, treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

  • The red kit or kit 5 is meant for genital ulcer disease - herpetic. It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days.

  • Chancroid, which manifests as numerous, tender soft, painful ulcers, & bilateral lymphadenopathy is a close differential diagnosis.

  • Chancroid, on the other hand, lacks vesicles and has deeper ulcers with ragged, undermined edges.

  • Only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis is the patient's history of penicillin drug allergy relevant.

  • They would need to be treated with a blue kit in this situation rather than a white kit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of Genital Herpes involves antiviral therapy, which is typically provided in the red kit.

  • It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days, which is effective against the herpes simplex virus.

questions.text: Ferruginous bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Asbestosis

 

 

Option C:

 

Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers. Ferruginous bodies are specifically associated with asbestos exposure. These bodies are formed when iron-containing proteins coat asbestos fibers in the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust.

 

Option B: Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease" or "Monday fever," is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of cotton, flax, or hemp dust.

 

Option D: Bagassosis: Bagassosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of dust from moldy sugarcane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ferruginous bodies are not typically associated with silicosis, byssinosis and bagassosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 701)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung. Which of the following is the earliest feature of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Recruitment of lymphocytes

 

Option B:

 

Recruitment of lymphocytes: The initial immune response to M. tuberculosis includes recruitment of lymphocytes to the site of infection. This is part of the early host defense, which precedes granuloma formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Caseation: Caseation, a form of necrosis typical of tuberculosis, is a later feature that occurs after the immune system has attempted to contain the infection.

 

Option C: Formation of giant cells (Langhans): Giant cell formation is part of the granuloma response and occurs after lymphocyte recruitment, as part of the body's attempt to wall off and contain the infection.

 

Option D: Granuloma formation: Granuloma formation is a hallmark of the body's defense against tuberculosis but is not the earliest event. It occurs after lymphocytes and macrophages have been recruited to the site of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recruitment of lymphocytes is the earliest feature in the immune response to M. tuberculosis infection. Following infection, lymphocytes are recruited, leading to the activation of macrophages and subsequent granuloma formation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 378)

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in the viral pneumonia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Predominance of alveolar exudate

 

Option B:

 

Predominance of alveolar exudate: Alveolar exudate is characteristic of bacterial pneumonia, where the alveoli are filled with fluid and inflammatory cells. This feature is less common in viral pneumonia, which tends to involve the interstitium and bronchioles more than the alveoli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presence of interstitial inflammation: This is a common feature in viral pneumonia, where the infection leads to inflammation predominantly in the tissue and space around the air sacs of the lungs.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis: Bronchiolitis, which is inflammation of the small airways or bronchioles, is commonly seen in viral pneumonia.

 

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall: The presence of multinucleate giant cells is a histopathological feature sometimes seen in viral infections, reflecting the body's response to viral replication within cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The predominance of alveolar exudate is not a feature commonly seen in viral pneumonia; instead, it is a hallmark of bacterial pneumonia. Viral pneumonia typically presents with interstitial inflammation, bronchiolitis, and can have multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall.

questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hours

 

Option C:

 

Presence of a coagulative necrotic pattern along with widened space between dead fibers and wavy fiber appearance sug­gests this to a pattern of injury taking place around 6 hours.

 

The described appearance of coagulative necrosis with widened spaces between dead fibers and a wavy fiber appearance is characteristic of the changes seen approximately 6 hours after an infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: At 1–2 days post-infarction, one would expect to see more infiltration by inflammatory cells, particularly neutrophils, and ongoing coagulative necrosis with loss of nuclei and striations, which is not the primary finding described.

 

Option B: By 3 weeks, the necrotic area would likely be undergoing repair, with granulation tissue and new collagen deposition, which is not indicated by the presence of coagulative necrosis and wavy fibers.

 

Option D: At 1 week, one would expect to see the beginnings of granulation tissue formation, which is not consistent with the early necrotic pattern described in the vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A coagulative necrotic pattern with widened spaces between dead fibers and wavy fiber appearance on a histological section of myocardium is suggestive of a myocardial injury that occurred around 6 hours prior.

questions.text: Which laboratory test parameter can indicate the highest relative risk for developing atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C- reactive protein

 

Option A:

 

C-reactive protein (CRP) is an inflammatory marker that when elevated, indicates endothelial cell activation and is associated with the development of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular risk.

 

  • C- reactive protein (CRP) is an acute phase reactant that causes endothelial cell activation, promote thrombosis and increases leukocyte adhesiveness in developing atheromas.

  • It is an independent predictor of CV risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Anti-proteinase 3 (PR3) is an antibody associated with vasculitis, specifically granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and is not a direct marker for atherosclerosis risk.

 

Option C: Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in the cold and are associated with cryoglobulinemic vasculitis but are not direct indicators of atherosclerotic risk.

 

Option D: Platelet count can reflect thrombotic risk but is not an independent predictor of atherosclerosis or cardiovascular disease like CRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRP is an acute-phase reactant that, when elevated, suggests systemic inflammation and is an independent risk factor for atherosclerosis and subsequent cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Which is associated with vasculitis of medium size vessels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyarteritis nodosa

 

Option C:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is associated with vasculitis of medium-sized vessels. It is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries, leading to inflammation, damage, and potential organ dysfunction. PAN can involve various organs, including the kidneys, heart, gastrointestinal tract, and nerves, due to the widespread nature of medium-sized artery inflammation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, primarily involves large and medium-sized arteries. It commonly affects the temporal arteries.

 

Option B: Wegener's granulomatosis (now known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis or GPA) involves small to medium-sized vessels, affecting the respiratory tract (nose, sinuses, and lungs) and sometimes the kidneys.

 

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura typically involves small vessels, such as capillaries and arterioles. It is characterized by immune-mediated inflammation of blood vessels, leading to symptoms like palpable purpura, joint pain, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational objective:

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is associated with vasculitis of medium-sized vessels associated with hepatitis B infection. 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 513)

questions.text: A 5‑year‑old child presents with perivascular IgA deposition and neutrophilic collection. There is erythematous rash on the lower limbs and non-blanching purpura. The likely diagnosis in the child is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Henoch-Schonlein Purpura

 

Option A:

 

HSP is a small-vessel vasculitis that commonly occurs in children. It is characterized by perivascular IgA deposition, neutrophilic infiltration, and involvement of small blood vessels. Skin manifestations often include a rash on the lower limbs, which may be erythematous and have non-blanching purpura.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Wegener's Granulomatosis: Wegener's granulomatosis is a form of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which primarily affects the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. It is not typically associated with IgA deposition.

 

Option C: Giant Cell Vasculitis: Giant cell vasculitis, such as giant cell arteritis, usually occurs in older individuals and involves large and medium-sized arteries. It is not commonly seen in children and does not present with the characteristic skin findings described.

 

Option D: Kawasaki's Disease: Kawasaki's disease is a vasculitis that affects medium-sized vessels, particularly the coronary arteries. While it can present with a rash, it is not associated with perivascular IgA deposition, which is a characteristic feature of HSP.

 

Educational objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small-vessel vasculitis that most commonly occurs in children and is characterized by a tetrad of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthralgia, and renal involvement. It is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection and is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the affected vessels.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 561)

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presented with bloating of abdomen and steatorrhea. His HLA DQ2 was positive. Which of the following is the diet modification helping in the improvement of the condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low gluten diet

 

Option C:

 

Celiac disease is treated by removing gluten from the diet, which is found in wheat, barley, rye, and their derivatives. This prevents the immune response that damages the small intestine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A low-fat diet can be recommended for specific conditions such as pancreatitis or gallbladder disease, but celiac disease primarily requires the elimination of gluten from the diet.

 

Option B. While a balanced diet is important, the focus for treating celiac disease is on removing gluten, which is the trigger for the autoimmune response causing the symptoms.

 

Option D. Reducing calorie intake does not have a role in the management of celiac disease unless there are concurrent issues with obesity or metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective dietary modification for a patient with celiac disease, suggested by the symptoms of malabsorption and a positive HLA DQ2, is a gluten-free diet.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /e p784

Ans. A) Crohn’s disease

Option A:

Characterized by granulomatous inflammation, which is one of the key histopathological features that can involve any segment of the GI tract. It is known for transmural inflammation, skip lesions, and granuloma formation.

questions.text: In Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, polyps are mainly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jejunum

 

Option D:

 

The polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) are most com­mon in the small intestine especially jejunum, although they may occur in the stomach and colon, and, with much lower frequency, in the bladder and lungs.

 

The jejunum is the most frequently affected site, and patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often develop polyps here that can cause complications like intussusception.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rectal involvement is possible in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, but it is not the primary site of polyp development.

 

Option B. The colon can be involved, but the small intestine, particularly the jejunum, is the most common site for polyps in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Esophageal polyps are quite uncommon in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, with the condition typically affecting the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jejunum is the most common site for the characteristic hamartomatous polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of chronic gastritis presents with weight loss and early satiety. An endoscopy with biopsy is performed, revealing a 2 cm lesion in the antrum of the stomach. Histopathology reports a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Additional staining shows the cancer is confined to the gastric wall with no evidence of metastasis. In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy is confined to which of the following layers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucosa and submucosa

 

Option B:

 

Involvement of both the mucosa and submucosa suggests a deeper invasion than option A but still within the confines of the stomach wall, representing an intermediate stage of disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. If a gastric carcinoma is confined to the mucosa, it indicates that the tumor has not penetrated beyond the innermost layer of the stomach, which is associated with a less aggressive disease and often a more favorable prognosis.

 

Option C. Penetration into the muscularis propria denotes a more advanced local invasion compared to options A and B, suggesting a higher risk of further spread and a worse prognosis if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Invasion of the serosa, the outermost layer of the stomach, implies that the tumor may be at the stage where it is capable of spreading beyond the stomach to adjacent structures or through the peritoneal surface, which would denote a more advanced and aggressive disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy confined to the mucosa and submucosa signifies a depth of invasion that is more advanced than the mucosal layer alone, but not yet extending into the muscularis propria or serosa.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 775

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) undergoes an upper endoscopy. Biopsy of the distal esophagus shows a change in the normal lining. Which of the following best characterizes Barrett’s esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intestinal columnar metaplasia

 

Option B:

 

Intestinal columnar  metaplasia This is the correct answer. Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal columnar metaplasia, where the normal stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells, as a response to chronic acid reflux.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intestinal dysplasia: This refers to precancerous changes within intestinal epithelium, which is not the finding typically associated with Barrett's esophagus. Dysplasia in Barrett’s esophagus is an important marker for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma but not the characteristic feature of Barrett's itself.

 

Option C. Simple columnar cell metaplasia: While Barrett's esophagus does involve a change to columnar epithelium, the specific subtype with goblet cells is intestinal metaplasia, making this option incomplete.

 

Option D. Columnar cell dysplasia: This would imply a precancerous change in the columnar cells, which is not indicated solely by the presence of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal columnar metaplasia, a histopathological change where the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium containing goblet cells, secondary to chronic GERD. This condition necessitates surveillance due to the increased risk of progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 757

questions.text: A 57-year-old lady diagnosed with Skin malignancy & she underwent chemotherapy, presents with hair loss after 3 weeks of starting of chemotherapy. Identify the INCORRECT statement about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair does not regrow once the Offending Agent is Stopped.

 

Option C.

  • It is incorrect. Typically, hair regrows after the cessation of chemotherapy, although it may have a different texture or color.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This condition is known as Anagen effluvium. Correct:

  • It is hair loss that occurs during the anagen or growth phase of the hair cycle, commonly induced by chemotherapy.
  • Hair regrows once offending chemotherapy agent is stopped.
  • It is due to the anagen, or proliferating phase of the hair cycle being adversely affected.
  • Following the start of chemotherapy, hair loss usually starts within 1-3 weeks and is finished within 1-2 months.

 

Option B. It is an example for Diffuse Hair Loss. Correct:

  • It is indeed an example of Diffuse hair loss, where hair loss occurs uniformly across the scalp, often because of systemic treatment like chemotherapy.

 

Option D. Hair loss finished within 1-2 months of chemotherapy. Correct:

  • It typically occurs rapidly after the start of chemotherapy and can continue for a short period after the therapy has concluded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced hair loss, or Anagen effluvium, is a type of Diffuse hair loss that generally resolves after the completion of chemotherapy, with hair regrowth occurring over time.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.7, 89.48

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of Werner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA helicase defect

 

Option D:

  • Werner syndrome in patients presents with premature aging, and the defective gene product is a DNA helicase, a protein involved in DNA replication and repair and other functions requiring DNA unwinding.
  • A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging.

Werner syndrome is caused by a defect in a DNA helicase enzyme, which is critical for DNA replication and repair. This defect leads to chromosomal damage and premature aging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Telomerase lengthening is typically related to cellular mechanisms that allow for unlimited replication, as seen in cancer cells, not premature aging.

 

Option B. Mutations in the lamin proteins are related to various disorders, including some forms of premature aging, but not specifically Werner syndrome.

 

Option C. While lipid peroxidation can contribute to cellular damage and aging, it is not the genetic etiology of Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genetic etiology of Werner syndrome is a defect in DNA helicase leading to premature aging due to the inability to properly replicate and repair DNA, which results in accelerated chromosomal damage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a painless lesion on her ear lobe (shown in the image) after getting her ears pierced 3 months ago. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maturation arrest of collagen assembly
 

Option D:

 

Keloid is a scar that tends to progress beyond the site of initial injury and recurs after excision. Dark-skinned persons are more frequently affected by keloids than light-skinned people. Keloids are characterized by changes in the ratio of type III to type I collagen, suggesting a “maturation arrest” in the healing process.

 

This is the hallmark of keloid formation. In keloids, there is an overproduction of collagen type I which is unable to reorganise itself into a proper scar. This results in a thickened and raised scar that grows beyond the boundary of the original wound.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While extracellular matrix components, including proteoglycans, play a role in wound healing, their turnover is not the primary defect in keloid formation.

 

Option B. Granulation tissue is the new connective tissue and microscopic blood vessels that form on the surfaces of a wound during the healing process. Exuberant granulation tissue can lead to hypertrophic scars, which are similar to keloids but do not grow beyond the boundaries of the original wound.

 

Option C. This process is more related to the formation of granulation tissue during wound healing. Although it is an essential part of the healing process, it does not specifically lead to keloids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In keloids, there is an imbalance in the synthesis and degradation of collagen, with an increase in the ratio of type I to type III collagen. This suggests a failure in the normal maturation process of collagen during wound healing, leading to the excessive scar formation typical of keloids.

 

Ref: https://journals.lww.com/prsgo/fulltext/2013/07000/keloids_and_hypertrophic_scars__update_and_future.5.aspx
